Introduction

Functional constipation is characterized by painful, infrequent, large-caliber or pellet-like stools without an underlying organic (ie, pathologic) cause.  Functional constipation is a benign condition and the most common cause of constipation in children (~95% of cases), with peak incidence between age 2 and 5.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Pediatric functional constipation occurs due to a cycle of voluntary stool withholding, chronic stool retention, and painful defecation, as follows:



  • Voluntary stool withholding:  Most common during certain developmental milestones, including the introduction of solid foods at age 6-12 months, the start of toilet training at age 2-3, and the start of school at age 4-5.  These transitions can alter stool consistency or lead to voluntary stool withholding (to avoid toileting in an unfamiliar environment).  The rectosigmoid colon stretches over time to accommodate the withheld stool, and the urge to defecate subsides.
  • Chronic stool retention:  The colon slowly absorbs water from the retained (ie, impacted) stool.  The stool hardens and continues to accumulate, causing worsening rectal distension (
    figure 1
    ).
  • Painful defecation:  The urge to defecate is infrequent, and the hard, large-caliber stools cause pain when passing.  Painful defecation reinforces the voluntary stool withholding, and the cycle repeats itself.


Progressive rectal dilation leads to intermittent, involuntary relaxation of the anal sphincter, resulting in encopresis (fecal incontinence), with leakage of soft, newly formed watery stool around the retained, impacted stool.



Risk factors for pediatric functional constipation include:



  • Behavioral factors:  Toilet training, reluctance to use unfamiliar toilets (eg, at school), and psychosocial stress (eg, new school, home, or sibling).
  • Dietary factors:  Introduction of solid foods, low fiber intake, high dairy/processed food intake, inadequate fluid intake.


Risk factors in older children and adolescents include sedentary lifestyle (eg, physical disability) and use of certain medications (eg, iron supplements, anticholinergics).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of pediatric functional constipation involves painful, infrequent (â‰¤2 per week), large-caliber or pellet-like stools, often with a history of encopresis (often mistaken as diarrhea).  Patients often have abdominal pain and bloating.  Patients with intellectual disability (eg, trisomy 21, fragile X syndrome) can experience an acute change in behavior (eg, headbanging, aggression); however, acute behavioral changes are not specific for constipation (

).  Physical examination may show a palpable fecal mass in the left lower quadrant, a dilated rectum with hard stool, and anal fissures from straining.



Of note, exclusively breastfed infants typically have 6-10 stools per day for the first month of life.  After the first month, the frequency of stools can decrease to 1 stool or less every 1-2 days, with some infants having only 1-2 stools per week.  This stool pattern is normal for exclusively breastfed infants and should not be confused with pediatric functional constipation.

Diagnosis



Functional constipation is a diagnosis of exclusion.  Organic causes of constipation are rare (~5% of cases) but should be considered and excluded before functional constipation is diagnosed (

).



If no organic cause is identified, the diagnosis of functional constipation is based on certain defined criteria (ie, Rome IV Criteria for Functional Constipation), including the patient experiencing at least 2 of the following for â‰¥1 months:



  • â‰¤2 stools per week.
  • History of voluntary stool withholding.
  • Hard or painful stools that may have blood on the outside.
  • Large-caliber stools.
  • Large, hard stool in the rectum.


For children age â‰¥4, the criteria also include:



  • â‰¥1 episodes of encopresis per week.
  • Large-caliber stools that obstruct the toilet.


Abdominal radiography is not necessary for routine evaluation of pediatric functional constipation.  However, in cases of limited historical or physical examination data (eg, obesity), demonstration of retained stool on abdominal radiography may be helpful for establishing the diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Hirschsprung disease:  Characterized by the congenital absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon and rectum that results in functional obstruction with increased rectal tone, delayed passage of meconium (ie, >48 hr) and abdominal distension shortly after birth.  Visualization of the transition zone (ie, dilated colon proximal to narrow aganglionic segment) with contrast enema is pathognomonic, and rectal biopsy is diagnostic.
  • Cystic fibrosis:  Genetic disorder that can present with meconium ileus (ie, delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension) in infancy.  Other manifestations include recurrent respiratory infections and pancreatic insufficiency with steatorrhea (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ).  Failure to thrive is common.
  • Neurologic disorders (eg, cerebral palsy, spinal dysraphism):  Can cause constipation due to intestinal hypotonia and paralysis.  Physical examination may show sacral anomalies or abnormal lower extremity findings (eg, weakness).
  • Infant dyschezia:  A common, benign functional stooling disorder characterized by straining to pass soft stool due to lack of coordination between abdominal muscle tension (ie, increased intraabdominal pressure) and pelvic floor muscle relaxation (
    figure 2
    ).  Infants typically cry, turn red in the face, and strain for >10 minutes before passing a soft stool.  This typically resolves by age 9 months as the gut nervous system matures.
  • Anorectal anomalies:  Includes a spectrum of congenital anomalies that can result in an imperforate or stenotic anus and subsequent constipation.  Patients with chromosomal abnormalities (eg, trisomy 21) or other congenital anomalies (eg, CHARGE syndrome) are at increased risk for anorectal anomalies.

Management



The management of pediatric functional constipation involves a multistep process that requires consistent and complete emptying of the bowel.  Over time, the bowel is retrained to pass soft stool at least once every other day.  The process includes:



  • Disimpaction:  In cases of moderate to severe stool retention (eg, encopresis), the colon and rectum are disimpacted before maintenance (preventive) therapy is initiated.  Disimpaction may involve oral medications, rectal medications, or a combination of both.  Osmotic laxatives (eg, polyethylene glycol) are preferred and cause fluid retention in the intestinal lumen, resulting in softer stool that is easily passed.  Stimulant laxatives cause intestinal peristalsis that can lead to intense abdominal cramping.  Sodium phosphate, saline, and mineral enemas cause rectal distension, which stimulates peristalsis.  However, in addition to abdominal cramping, enemas are invasive and can cause electrolyte imbalances.  Disimpaction is generally not required for patients with mild to moderate stool retention, and these patients can begin with maintenance therapy.
  • Daily maintenance therapy:  Following disimpaction, patients require daily maintenance therapy to prevent relapse.  An osmotic laxative is effective in most cases, and the dose should be titrated to effect by increasing the dose until the patient has soft, daily stools (generally type 3 or 4 on the Bristol stool form scale (
    figure 3
    )) or decreasing the dose if the patient has diarrhea.  Rarely, a stimulant laxative is necessary to prevent constipation.  When soft, daily bowel movements are well established (eg, â‰¥6 months), daily maintenance therapy may be slowly weaned; however, caregivers should watch for signs of relapse (eg, abdominal pain, hard stool, encopresis).
  • Behavioral modifications:  In addition to daily maintenance therapy, behavioral modifications involving timed toilet-sitting after meals (ie, 5-10 min with feet supported and knees above hips) should be encouraged.  Positive reinforcement (rewards) may be necessary to ensure cooperation.  Negative reinforcement (punishment) should be avoided to prevent stool withholding and relapse.
  • Dietary and lifestyle changes:  Dietary and lifestyle changes include increased fiber intake (eg, fruits, vegetables, whole grains) and hydration while limiting cow's milk (ie, <24 oz per day) and processed foods.  Physical activity should be encouraged to promote bowel motility.


Constipation in infants after introduction to solid foods can often be managed with the addition of apple, prune, or pear juice/puree.  These fruits contain nondigestible, osmotically active carbohydrates (eg, sorbitol) that soften the stool by pulling water into the intestinal lumen.  Osmotic laxatives can be considered for infants with constipation refractory to dietary changes.

Prognosis



The prognosis for pediatric functional constipation is favorable with compliance.  Relapse is common and requires briefly increasing the dose of the osmotic laxative used for daily maintenance therapy.  If unsuccessful, a stimulant laxative or enema may be administered, followed by immediate resumption of daily maintenance therapy.



Frequent relapses despite compliance with daily maintenance therapy, behavioral modifications, and dietary and lifestyle changes warrant further evaluation (eg, anorectal manometry, colon transit study) for an alternate diagnosis.  Although benign, untreated pediatric functional constipation can lead to complications, including:



  • Psychosocial issues:  Untreated pediatric functional constipation can lead to fecal incontinence and psychosocial distress, especially in school-aged patients.
  • Urinary stasis:  Impacted stool dilates the rectum, which can compress the bladder and urethra (
    figure 4
    ).  This can prevent complete voiding and lead to urinary retention and stasis.  In addition, impacted stool can cause or worsen nocturnal enuresis and should be considered in any patient with enuresis.

Prevention



The most effective strategy for the prevention of pediatric functional constipation is to establish healthy bowel habits (eg, not withhold stool) at a young age.  In addition, adequate fiber intake and hydration, as well as low-stress toilet training are essential.

Summary



Functional constipation (

) is characterized by painful, infrequent, large-caliber or pellet-like stools without an underlying organic (ie, pathologic) cause.  Pediatric functional constipation occurs due to a cycle of voluntary stool withholding, chronic stool retention, and painful defecation, often after introducing solid foods, starting toilet training, starting school (ie, avoiding unfamiliar toilets), or experiencing psychosocial stress.  A diagnosis of exclusion, pediatric functional constipation is managed with disimpaction (ie, osmotic laxatives with or without enemas) followed by daily maintenance therapy (ie, osmotic laxatives), behavioral modifications, and lifestyle changes.
